title: 111-D
statement: D. Petya and Coloringtime limit per test5 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutLittle Petya loves counting. He wants to count the number of ways to paint a rectangular checkered board of sizen×m(nrows,mcolumns) inkcolors. Besides, the coloring should have the following property: for any vertical line that passes along the grid lines and divides the board in two non-empty parts the number of distinct colors in both these parts should be the same. Help Petya to count these colorings.InputThe first line contains space-separated integersn,mandk(1 ≤n,m≤ 1000, 1 ≤k≤ 106) — the board's vertical and horizontal sizes and the number of colors respectively.OutputPrint the answer to the problem. As the answer can be quite a large number, you should print it modulo109+ 7(1000000007).ExamplesInput2 2 1Output1Input2 2 2Output8Input3 2 2Output40

processed.result: You are given a rectangular grid of size $n \times m$ and $k$ colors.  Find the number of ways to color the grid so that for any vertical line dividing the grid into two non-empty parts, the number of distinct colors in each part is the same.  The answer should be modulo $10^9 + 7$.

You have a rectangular grid.  You need to color each cell of the grid with one of several colors.  The coloring must be such that every vertical line dividing the grid in half results in both halves having the same number of distinct colors.  How many ways can you color the grid?
